references: Iverson, J. B. 1977. Kinosternon subrubrum. Cat. Am. Amph. Rep. 193.1-193.4.
Ernst, C. H., and R. W. Barbour. 1972. Turtles of the United States. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 347 pp.
Burke, V. J., J. W. Gibbons, and J. L. Greene. 1994. Prolonged nesting forays by common mud turtles (Kinosternon subrubrum). Am. Midl. Nat 131:190-195.
Houseal, T. W., and J. L. Carr. 1983. Notes on the repro- duction of KINOSTERNON SUBRUBRUM (Testudines:Kinosternidae)in east Texas. Southwest. Nat. 28:237-248.
Frazer, N. B., J. W. Gibbons, and J. L. Greene. 1991. Life history and demography of the common mud turtle KINOSTERNON SUBRUBRUM in South Carolina, USA. Ecology 72:2218-2231.
Iverson, J. B. 1979. Reproduction and growth of the mud turtle, Kinosternon subrubrum (Reptilia, Testudines, Kinosternidae), in Arkansas. J. Herpetol. 13:105-111.
Lovich, J. E., and T. Lamb. 1995. Morphometric similarity between the turtles KINOSTERNON SUBRUBRUM HIPPOCREPIS and K. BAURII. Journal of Herpetology 29:621-624.
Iverson, J. B. 1991. Phylogenetic hypotheses for the evolution of modern kinosternine turtles. Herpetological Monographs 5:1-27.
Gibbons, J. W. 1983. Reproductive characteristics and ecology of the mud turtle, KINOSTERNON SUBRUBRUM (Lacepede).Herpetologica 39:254-271.
habitat_description:
The range of the eastern mud turtle extends across the eastern and southern region of the United States; Indiana, New York, south-central Texas, and Oklahoma (Natureserve.org). This species is regarded as a benthic species that burrows in or using soil, ground litter, and decaying logs. 

Primarily found in low gradient creeks, and shallow water pools, this species also ventures into riparian zones such as herbaceous and forested wetlands. Preferred habitat characteristics include non-flowing fresh or brackish water, soft bottoms, wet meadows, and dense vegetative cover. Often found on terrestrial sites up to 135 meters from wetlands during periods of inactivity (Buhlmann and Gibbons 2001). Nesting sites are found in open areas of soft soil in close proximity to water. Other sites for nesting are muskrat tunnels, ground litter, and cover provided by vegetation (Ernst and Barbour 1972).

*Mud turtles are considered sedentary but sometimes also move many kilometers across wetland and upland habitats to find suitable nesting areas or isolated ponds or wetlands (Natureserve.org).
